column1: '''1961 Jan Broberg''' refers to an interview with [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]
column2: conducted by [[Jan Broberg]] in Bournemouth in [[1961]].

column1: According to [[Wayne G. Hammond]] and [[Christina Scull]]
column2: the interview took place during Tolkien's stay at Hotel Miramar in Bournemouth

column1: The interview was first published in Swedish newspaper ''Kvällsposten'' (Malmö
column2: 27 July 1961) as "<nowiki>'</nowiki>''Sagan om ringen''<nowiki>'</nowiki> ingen allegori: ff-författaren vill ge avkoppling" ("<nowiki>'</nowiki>''The Lord of the Rings''<nowiki>'</nowiki> is no Allegory: The Author of F[antasy] F[iction] Wants to Give Relaxation"). A heavily revised version of the interview was later published as "Tillsammans med Tolkien" ("Together with Tolkien") in Broberg's 1985 book ''[[I fantasins världar]]''.<ref>[[Åke Bertenstam|Bertenstam
column3: Åke]]: ''Chronological Bibliography of Books About Tolkien''</ref>

column2: a translation into English by John-Henri Holmberg of the interview
column3: together with an introduction and notes by [[Morgan Thomsen]] and [[Shaun Gunner]]
column4: was published as the article "Two Swedish Interviews with J.R.R. Tolkien" in [[Hither Shore 9|''Hither Shore'' 9]].

column1: For many, many years, I have been fascinated by the fairy-tale as a means of expression
column2: [Tolkien] says thoughtfully. "I used to write without a thought of publishing anything of what I have produced
column3: a number of letters to my children from Father Christmas and other. I was very early fascinated by such works as Beowulf and the Edda and by different languages - I even invented my own languages..."

column2: p.93: "Jag har varit fascinerad av sagan som uttrycksform i många
column4: säger han eftertänksamt. "Jag skrev länge utan en tanke på att publicera något av det jag åstadkommit
column5: en rad brev till mina barn från jultomten och annat. Jag fascinerades mycket tidigt av sådana verk som Beowulf och Eddan och av olika språk - jag uppfann till och med egna språk..."]</small>
